revision.text:
[[File:Кристинопольский апостол.JPG|right|thumb|ff.110v–111r of the Apostolus Christinopolitanus, before and after the restoration of 2007–08]] The '''Apostolus Christinopolitanus''' is a [[Cyrillic]] manuscript of the Acts and Epistles with commentary, written in [[Church Slavonic]] of the East Slavonic recension in the middle of the twelfth century. It takes its name from the town of Krystynopol (now [[Chervonohrad]]), where it was kept until 1908. The greater part of the manuscript (291 leaves), is now in the Historical Museum in [[Lviv|Ľviv]] (MS 37); a further 8 leaves are in the [[Vernadsky National Library of Ukraine|National Library]] of the Ukraine in [[Kiev]] (MS VIII.3).<ref>''Сводный каталог славяно-русских рукописных книг, хранящихся в СССР, XI-XIII вв.,'' Moscow: Nauka,1984, №59, 60. This incorrectly gives the Ľviv shelfmark as 39, repeating a frequent error; cf. М.А. Бобрик, “Терминология библейской цитаты и толкования в рукописях Толкового Апостола XII – XVI веков”, ''Библеистика. Славистика. Русистика: К 70-летию ... А. А. Алексеева,'' СПб.: Филологический факультет СПбГУ, 2011, pp.387−398.</ref>
The manuscript in its present condition is incomplete, lacking Acts i 1 – ix 27 and xiii 6–19, I Peter ii 11-25, I Timothy iv 8 – vi 21, and all of II Timothy, Titus and Philemon. Unusually, the Epistle to the Hebrews is placed between II Thessalonians and I Timothy. The epistles are accompanied by the prefaces and chapter-lists of the [[Euthalian Apparatus]] and by extensive commentary. The manuscript is very unusual in having the scriptural text occupying the central area of the page and the commentary in smaller writing in the wide margins surrounding it, an arrangement common in Greek manuscripts but almost unknown in the Slavonic tradition, where the text and commentary usually occupy the same central area.
The Apostolus Christinopolitanus was published in 1896 by Emil Kałużniacki,<ref>Kałużniacki, Aem. ''Actus epistolaeque apostolorum palaeoslovenicе, Ad fidem codicis Christinopolitani saeculo XII scripti,'' Vindobonae, 1896</ref> who however printed only the scriptural text (supplying the missing parts with text from other manuscripts) and omitted the commentary. After a thorough restoration of the manuscript, carried out in 2007 and 2008, a digital facsimile was made available by the National Library.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lhm.lviv.ua/proekty/krystynopolskyy_apostol.html|title=Кристинопольський Апостол|language=Ukrainian}}</ref>
The text of the Apostolus Christinopolitanus, in Kałużniacki′s edition, was used as a source for Slavonic variants to the Greek New Testament in the [[United Bible Societies]]′ edition, somewhat unfortunately, as the editors failed to notice that some of the variants actually come from the other manuscripts used by Kałużniacki,<ref>M. Bakker, ″The Slavonic Version in UBS<sup>4</sup>″, ''Novum Testamentum'' 37 (1995), 92-94.</ref> and because, despite the antiquity of the manuscript, the text is not a good witness to the earliest Slavonic version: in common with other manuscripts that include commentary, it ″bears the marks of revision and subsequent influence from Greek manuscripts".<ref>H.P.S. Bakker, ''Towards a Critical Edition of the Old Slavic New Testament,'' Amsterdam, 1996: 108.</ref> The manuscript nevertheless has considerable linguistic and text-critical importance for the Slavonic version, particularly when the commentary is taken into account.
==References== <references/>
[[Category:Manuscripts]]
{{manuscript-stub}}

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox philosopher | region = [[Western philosophy]] | era = [[20th-century philosophy]] | name = Arthur Norman Prior | birth_date = {{Birth date|1914|12|4|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Masterton]], New Zealand | death_date = {{Death date and age|1969|10|6|1914|12|4|df=yes}} | death_place = [[Trondheim]], Norway | alma_mater = [[University of Otago]]<ref>[https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/prior/ Arthur Prior (Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy)]</ref> | school_tradition = [[Analytic philosophy]] | main_interests = [[Philosophical logic]], [[modal logic]] | influences = [[John Niemeyer Findlay]], [[Józef Maria Bocheński]], [[Jan Łukasiewicz]], [[Charles Sanders Peirce]], [[William Ernest Johnson]] | influenced = [[John Lemmon]], [[Max Cresswell]], [[Robert Bull]], [[Kit Fine]], [[Ruth Barcan Marcus]]<ref>[[Ruth Barcan Marcus]], ''Modalities: Philosophical Essays'', Oxford University Press, 1993, p. x.</ref> | notable_ideas = [[Tense logic]], [[intensional logic]], [[Prior's tonk]] }}
'''Arthur Norman Prior''' (4 December 1914 – 6 October 1969), usually cited as '''A. N. Prior''', was a noted [[logic]]ian and philosopher. Prior (1957) founded tense logic, now also known as [[temporal logic]], and made important contributions to [[intensional logic]], particularly in Prior (1971).
==Biography== Prior was born in [[Masterton]], New Zealand, on 4 December 1914, the only child of Australian-born parents: Norman Henry Prior (1882–1967) and his wife born Elizabeth Munton Rothesay Teague (1889–1914). His mother died less than 3 weeks after his birth and he was cared for by his father's sister. His father, a medical practitioner in general practice, remarried in 1920 and there were three more children. Prior grew up in a Methodist home and both of his grandfathers came to Australia as missionaries. His father Norman Prior was a doctor who was decorated for his service as medical officer in the first world war.<ref>https://www.wairarapa100.co.nz/norman-prior</ref>
Prior was educated entirely in [[New Zealand]], where he was fortunate to have come under the influence of [[John Niemeyer Findlay]]. Despite knowing only modest mathematics, he began teaching philosophy and logic at [[Canterbury University College]] in 1946, filling the vacancy created by [[Karl Popper]]'s resignation. In 1951 Prior met [[J.J.C. Smart]], also known as "Jack" Smart, at a philosophical conference in Australia and the two developed a life-long friendship. Their correspondence was influential on Prior's development of tense-logic. Smart adhered to the tenseless theory of time and was never persuaded by Prior's arguments, though Prior was influential in making Smart skeptical about [[Wittgenstein]]'s view on pseudo-relations. <ref>http://aauforlag.dk/UserFiles/file/Logic_and_Philosophy_of_Themes_from_Prior_ONLINE.pdf</ref>He became Professor in 1953. Thanks to the good offices of [[Gilbert Ryle]], who had met Prior in New Zealand in 1954, Prior spent the year 1956 on leave at the [[University of Oxford]], where he gave the [[John Locke]] [[John Locke lectures|lectures]] in philosophy. These were subsequently published as ''Time and Modality'' (1957). This is a seminal contribution to the study of tense logic and the metaphysics of time, in which Prior championed the A-theorist view that the temporal modalities past, present and future are basic ontological categories of fundamental importance for our understanding of time and the world. During his time at Oxford, Prior met [[Peter Geach]] and [[William Kneale (logician)|William Kneale]], influenced [[John Lemmon]], and corresponded with the adolescent [[Saul Kripke]]. Logic in the United Kingdom was then in a rather low state, and Prior's enthusiasm is believed to have contributed materially to its revival.{{citation needed|date=November 2012}} From 1959 to 1966, he was Professor of Philosophy at the [[University of Manchester]], having taught [[Osmund Lewry]]. From 1966 until his death he was Fellow and Tutor in philosophy at [[Balliol College, Oxford]]. His students include [[Max Cresswell]], [[Kit Fine]], and [[Robert Bull]].
Almost entirely self-taught in modern [[formal logic]], Prior published his first paper on logic in 1952, when he was already 38 years of age, shortly after discovering the work of [[Józef Maria Bocheński]] and [[Jan Łukasiewicz]], very little of whose work was then translated into English.{{citation needed|date=November 2012}} He went on to employ [[Polish notation]] throughout his career. Prior (1955) distills much of his early teaching of logic in New Zealand. Prior's work on tense logic provides a systematic and extended defence of a tensed conception of reality in which material objects are construed as three-dimensional continuants which are wholly present at each moment of their existence.
Prior stood out by virtue of his strong interest in the history of logic. He was one of the first English-speaking logicians to appreciate the nature and scope of the logical work of [[Charles Sanders Peirce]], and the distinction between ''[[de dicto]]'' and ''[[de re]]'' in [[modal logic]]. Prior taught and researched [[modal logic]] before Kripke proposed his [[Kripke semantics|possible worlds semantics]] for it, at a time when modality and intentionality commanded little interest in the English speaking world, and had even come under sharp attack by [[Willard Van Orman Quine]].
He is now said to be the precursor of [[hybrid logic]].<ref name="CarnielliPizzi2008">{{cite book| author1=Walter Carnielli| author2=Claudio Pizzi| title=Modalities and Multimodalities| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XpAFM04G6BAC&pg=PA181| year=2008| publisher=Springer| isbn=978-1-4020-8589-5| page=181 }}</ref> Undertaking (in one section of his book ''Past, Present, and Future'' (1967)) the attempt to combine binary (e.g., "until") and unary (e.g., "will always be") temporal operators to one system of [[temporal logic]], Prior—as an incidental result—builds a base for later hybrid languages.
His work ''Time and Modality'' explored the use of a [[many-valued logic]] to explain the problem of [[non-referring names]].
Prior's work was both philosophical and formal and provides a productive synergy between formal innovation and linguistic analysis.{{citation needed|date=November 2012}} [[Natural language]], he remarked, can embody folly and confusion as well as the wisdom of our ancestors. He was scrupulous in setting out the views of his adversaries, and provided many constructive suggestions about the formal development of alternative views.
==Publications== The following books were either written by Prior, or are posthumous collections of journal articles and unpublished papers that he wrote: * 1949. ''Logic and the Basis of Ethics''. [[Oxford University Press]] ({{ISBN|0-19-824157-7}}) * 1955, 1962. ''Formal Logic''. Oxford University Press. * 1957. ''Time and Modality''. Oxford University Press. based on his 1956 [[John Locke lectures]]. * 1962. "Changes in Events and Changes in Things". University of Kansas. * 1967. ''Past, Present and Future''. Oxford University Press. * 1968. ''Papers on Time and Tense''. Oxford University Press. * 1971. ''Objects of Thought''. Edited by [[P. T. Geach]] and [[A. J. P. Kenny]]. Oxford University Press. * 1976. ''The Doctrine of Propositions and Terms''. Edited by P. T. Geach and A. J. P. Kenny. London: [[Gerald Duckworth and Company|Duckworth]]. * 1976. ''Papers in Logic and Ethics''. Edited by P. T. Geach and A. J. P. Kenny. London: Duckworth. * 1977. ''Worlds, Times and Selves''. Edited by Kit Fine. London: Duckworth. * 2003. ''Papers on Time and Tense''. Second expanded edition by Per Hasle, Peter Øhrstrøm, Torben Braüner & [[Jack Copeland]]. Oxford University Press.
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== The nearest thing to a biography of Prior is:
* [[Jack Copeland|Copeland, B. J.]], 1996, "Prior's Life and Legacy," in his edited volume ''Logic and Reality: Essays on the Legacy of Arthur Prior'', New York: Oxford University Press (pp. 519–32 of this volume contain a complete bibliography of Prior's known writings as of date).
An excellent survey of Prior's life and achievement is: * [[A. J. P. Kenny]] 1970, 'Arthur Norman Prior (1914–1969)' ''Proceedings of the British Academy'' 56: 321–349. * Dr. Mary Prior's recollection of Arthur Prior's life and work: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8Vgr74kyf3g
Ongoing research on the importance of Prior's philosophy and logic: * Logic and Philosophy of Time: Themes from Prior. http://aauforlag.dk/UserFiles/file/Logic_and_Philosophy_of_Themes_from_Prior_ONLINE.pdf
==External links== *{{cite SEP |url-id=prior |title=Arthur Prior |last=Copeland |first=B. Jack}} * [http://www.prior.aau.dk/ Foundations of Temporal Logic The WWW-site for Prior-studies] * [http://hylo.loria.fr/content/papers/files/tense.pdf On Prior's Tense Logic] by Patrick Blackburn * [http://conference.prior.aau.dk/ Arthur Prior Centenary Conference, Balliol College, Oxford, 21 – 22 August, 2014] * [http://nachlass.prior.aau.dk Prior's Nachlass]
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Prior, Arthur}} [[Category:1914 births]] [[Category:1969 deaths]] [[Category:People from Masterton]] [[Category:University of Canterbury faculty]] [[Category:New Zealand emigrants to the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Academics of the University of Manchester]] [[Category:Fellows of Balliol College, Oxford]] [[Category:New Zealand logicians]] [[Category:Mathematical logicians]] [[Category:Analytic philosophers]] [[Category:New Zealand philosophers]] [[Category:20th-century philosophers]] [[Category:Philosophy of time]]

revision.text:
'''Brian Leftow''' (born 1956) is the [[Nolloth Professor of the Philosophy of the Christian Religion]] at [[Oriel College]], [[University of Oxford|Oxford]], succeeding [[Richard Swinburne]], who retired in 2002. In fall 2018, he will join the faculty at [[Rutgers University]].
==Education and career==
He is a graduate of [[Grove City College]], and earned his M.A and Ph.D. at [[Yale University]].<ref>Fordham University [http://www.fordham.edu/philosophy/Faculty/leftow.htm Fordham University] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090707012127/http://www.fordham.edu/philosophy/Faculty/leftow.htm |date=July 7, 2009 }}</ref> Before occupying the Nolloth chair at the University of Oxford, Leftow taught at [[Fordham University]]. In fall 2018, he will take up the [[William P. Alston]] Chair in Philosophy of Religion at [[Rutgers University]].<ref>http://dailynous.com/2017/12/22/leftow-oxford-rutgers/</ref>
==Philosophical work==
Leftow's research interests include [[metaphysics]], [[medieval philosophy]], and [[philosophical theology]].<ref>[http://www.closertotruth.com/participant/Brian-Leftow/54 "Closer to Truth"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100707000608/http://www.closertotruth.com/participant/Brian-Leftow/54 |date=July 7, 2010 }}</ref>
== Selected publications == *''God and Necessity'' (2012) *''Divine Ideas'', Ithaca: [[Cornell University Press]], forthcoming. *''Matter, Parts and Number: Aquinas' Philosophy of Mathematics''. Oxford, forthcoming. *"Anti Social Trinitarianism," in Steven Davis and Daniel Kendall, eds., ''The Trinity''. New York: Oxford University Press, 1999. *"The Eternal Now," in Gregory Ganssle and David Woodruff, eds., ''God and Time''. Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2002. *"Necessary Being", and "Concepts of God," in ''The Encyclopedia of Philosophy''. London: Routledge Press, 1998. *"Anselm on the Cost of Salvation," ''Medieval Philosophy and Theology''. 1997. *"Eternity," in ''The Cambridge Companion to Philosophy of Religion'', ed. [[Philip Quinn]] and [[Charles Taliaferro]]. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1997. *"Divine Action and Embodiment," Proceedings of the American Catholic Philosophical Association, 1997. *"Can Philosophy Argue God's Existence?" in The Rationality of Belief and The Plurality of Faith, ed. Tom Senor. Ithaca, NY: Cornell University Press, 1995. *''Time and Eternity''. Ithaca, NY: Cornell University Press, 1991.
== References == {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Leftow, Brian}} [[Category:20th-century philosophers]] [[Category:21st-century philosophers]] [[Category:Analytic philosophers]] [[Category:Christian philosophers]] [[Category:Metaphysicians]] [[Category:Philosophers of religion]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Grove City College alumni]] [[Category:Yale University alumni]] [[Category:Fordham University faculty]] [[Category:Nolloth Professors of the Philosophy of the Christian Religion]] [[Category:Fellows of Oriel College, Oxford]] [[Category:Converts to Christianity]] [[Category:1956 births]]

'''Carlos Santiago Nino''' (1943–1993) was an [[Argentina|Argentine]] [[ethics|moral]], [[Philosophy of law|legal]] and [[Political philosophy|political]] [[philosopher]].
==Biography== Nino studied law at the University of [[Buenos Aires]] and at [[Oxford]], where he received his Ph.D. in 1977 with a thesis directed by [[John Finnis]] and [[Tony Honoré]].
Nino began his academic activity in the early 1970s, concentrating on some traditional issues in [[jurisprudence]], such as the concept of a legal [[system]], the [[statutory interpretation|interpretation]] of the law, the debate between [[legal positivism]] and [[natural law]], and the concept of [[Validity (logic)|validity]].<ref>see ''Notas de introducción al Derecho'', Buenos Aires, 1973, expanded in ''Introducción al análisis del Derecho'', Buenos Aires, 1980.</ref> After realizing the need to clarify the normative problems involved in some of those issues, he was led to embrace a model based on the explicit adoption of principles of justice and social morality, rejecting the predominant [[Germany|German]]-inspired "dogmatic" approach.<ref>See ''Consideraciones sobre la dogmática jurídica'', México, 1974; and ''Algunos modelos metodológicos de "ciencia" jurídica'', Valencia, 1980.</ref> This signaled the beginning of his [[philosophical]] investigations, which were always oriented to practical issues, and marked by a distinctively [[Analysis (philosophy)|analytical]] approach. His need to provide a [[Liberalism|liberal]] justification for criminal law practice thus lead him to [[ethics|moral philosophy]], and to the development of an original "consensual" theory of [[punishment]] which combined the merits of the retributive and [[utilitarianism|utilitarian]] (see [[deterrence (psychology)|deterrence]]) varieties while avoiding their respective difficulties.<ref>See ''Towards a General Strategy for Criminal Law Adjudication'', unpublished Ph.D. thesis 1977; revised Spanish translation, ''Los límites de la responsabilidad penal'', Buenos Aires, 1980.</ref> Similarly, the problems presented by the characterization of criminal conduct stimulated his work in the field of [[philosophy of action]].<ref>(see ''Introducción a la filosofía de la acción humana'', Buenos Aires, 1987.</ref>
During the early 1980s, after the restoration of [[democracy]], Nino became engaged in politics, serving as personal assistant to President [[Raúl Alfonsín]] and as coordinator of his newly created "Consejo para la consolidación de la democracia", a special committee for the study and design of institutional reforms. His theoretical activities, however, were not forgotten: in 1984 he published his monumental ''Ética y derechos humanos'',<ref>Buenos Aires; English revised translation, ''The Ethics of Human Rights'', Oxford, 1991</ref> dedicated to Alfonsín, where he provided a comprehensive exposition of his moral thought; divided in three parts, it dealt with [[normative ethics|normative]] and [[applied ethics]], as well as with [[meta-ethics]]. This last field he expanded in a separate volume,<ref>''El constructivismo ético'', Madrid, 1989</ref> where he adopted a constructivist approach that attempted to derive his fundamental ethical principles from the presuppositions of moral discourse, in a manner that put him, as he said, "between [[John Rawls|Rawls]] and [[Jürgen Habermas|Habermas]]". These substantive principles, comprising the nucleus of a theory that aspired to capture the essential components of [[political liberalism]], were the principle of [[autonomy]], the principle of [[Sanctity of life|inviolability]], and the principle of [[dignity]]. The first expressed Nino's conception of the [[Value theory|good]]: those things, and those things only, that were valued by the individual in question. The second imposed deontological restrictions to the pursuit of that good, prohibiting the sacrifice of some to achieve the benefit of others. The third principle allowed for individual consent, thus permitting persons to waive the rights recognized by the second one.
With this solid normative foundation, Nino went to tackle some practical issues, such as [[abortion]], [[capital punishment]], and [[Psychoactive drug|drug]] regulation. On the former, he proposed a gradualist approach similar to the [[United States|American]] one, recognizing rights to the [[fetus]]es only when they showed the cognitive and affective capacities necessary for considering them moral persons. As regards death penalty, he was firmly opposed to it—as he was to the criminalization of drug consumption.
While on trip to [[La Paz, Bolivia]] in 1993 to work on the reform of the [[Bolivia]]n constitution, Nino had an asthma attack and subsequently died. This tragedy killed a man who appeared to be at the peak of his productivity: the year before he had published two books,<ref>''Un país al margen de la ley'', Buenos Aires; and ''Fundamentos de derecho constitucional'', Buenos Aires</ref> served as editor to two others,<ref>''El presidencialismo puesto a prueba'', Madrid; and ''Rights'', New York</ref> and had given the manuscripts of a couple more to his friend [[Owen Fiss]], who assumed the responsibility of readying them for publication. ''The Constitution of Deliberative Democracy'' and ''Radical Evil on Trial'' saw the light in 1996. In the first he developed his "epistemic justification" of [[deliberative democracy]], arguing that democratic deliberation provides better reasons to believe in the validity of moral norms than private reflection. The second is a moving personal description of the [[Trial of the Juntas|military junta trials]]; it provides a testimony to his unique ability to approach public affairs with both philosophical sophistication and political commitment.
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.stafforini.com/blog/carlos-santiago-nino-a-bibliography/ Carlos Santiago Nino: a bibliography]. A complete list of writings.
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Nino, Carlos Santiago}} [[Category:1943 births]] [[Category:1993 deaths]] [[Category:Argentine philosophers]] [[Category:Argentine sociologists]] [[Category:Place of birth missing]] [[Category:Deaths from asthma]] [[Category:Guggenheim Fellows]]

revision.text:
'''Carolyn Korsmeyer''' (born 1950) is an author and Professor of Philosophy at the [[University of Buffalo]] in New York. She is generally recognized for her study and research on [[aesthetics]], [[feminism]], and [[emotion theory]].{{cite web|title=Carolyn Korsmeyer|url=http://www.philosophy.buffalo.edu/people/faculty/korsmeyer/|accessdate=21 July 2013}} == Career == Carolyn received her Ph.D. from [[Brown University]] in 1972. In 1978, she began working as a professor of [[Philosophy]] at the University of Buffalo where she continues to work today as the Head of the Philosophy Department.{{cite web|title=Carolyn Korsmeyer|url=http://library.buffalo.edu/archives/womens_work/bios/korsmeyer.htm|work=2012|publisher=University of Buffalo|accessdate=21 July 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140305010343/http://library.buffalo.edu/archives/womens_work/bios/korsmeyer.htm#|archive-date=2014-03-05|dead-url=yes|df=}} Since beginning her career at the University of Buffalo, Korsmeyer has been recognized multiple times for her outstanding performance and continued achievements for her work both in and away from Philosophy. During her long career, Korsmeyer has published multiple acclaimed articles and books on feminism and aesthetics. == Overview of major work == After receiving her PhD in 1972, Korsmeyer began to focus her research on feminist philosophy and the field of aesthetics. Feminist perspectives in aesthetics has long been major work of Korsmeyer. Fine art, genius, beauty, taste, and aesthetic perception are gendered issues that she has studied and researched.{{cite web|last=Koopman|first=Constantijn|title=Essay review of Gender and Aesthetics: An Introduction|url=http://act.maydaygroup.org/articles/Koopman5_1.pdf|publisher=Action, Criticism, and Theory for Music Education|accessdate=25 July 2013}} === Philosophy of taste === The [[philosophy of taste]] is a relatively new subject in the field of philosophy, however Korsmeyer's study of "bad taste" is well known. Her consideration of taste in philosophy explores why pungent food like soured milk, fried bugs, extremely hot peppers, and game meat are seen as strong and complex to our palettes.{{cite book|last=Korsmeyer|first=Carolyn|title=Making Sense of Food and Taste: Food and Philosophy|url=https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=20ltkqE2s1UC&oi=fnd&pg=PP13&dq=Carolyn+Korsmeyer&ots=m8VqoRzxQR&sig=jcuJ1Zd9LaQBy02TxjJrJm90Agc#v=onepage&q=Carolyn%20Korsmeyer&f=false|publisher=Cornell University Press|accessdate=25 July 2013}} A theoretical understanding of taste of food is compared to the philosophy and interpretation of art in that both deem the similar qualities that entail discriminating perception and also that food and art are both considered 'artistic in creation.' The argument Korsmeyer presents is that these "cosmopolitan foods" are so complex that they lie on a nearly transparent line straddling between the sublime and disgusting and, when the brain is given the choice, usually the positive reaction wins. Thus, these seemingly disgusting foods give a positive aesthetic response.
Her publications on the subject include:{{cite web|url=http://www.acsu.buffalo.edu/~ckors/|title=Carolyn Korsmeyer|accessdate=26 July 2013}} *''Savoring Disgust: The Foul and the Fair in Aesthetics'' (Oxford University Press, 2011) *''The Taste Culture Reader: Experiencing Food and Drink (ed.)'' (Oxford: Berg Publishers 2005) *''Making Sense of Taste: Food and Philosophy'' (Ithaca: Cornell University Press, 1999) === Feminist perspectives in aesthetics === [[Feminist aesthetics]] refers to the idea that in their basic form, classic concepts such as genius, beauty, fine art, aesthetic perception cradle social roles are qualities that are presumed as gender related.{{cite web|last=Korsmeyer|first=Carolyn|title=Feminist Aesthetics|url=http://plato.stanford.edu/cgi-bin/encyclopedia/archinfo.cgi?entry=feminism-aesthetics|publisher=The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy (Winter 2012 Edition)|accessdate=20 July 2013}} In her most notorious book titled ''Gender and Aesthetics: An Introduction to Understanding Feminist Philosophy'' (London: Routledge, 2004) Korsmeyer uses these "classic concepts" to identify their qualities and goes on to explain the weight of gender as the abiding attribute. Genius, for example, is said to be 'superior in mind' which has long been associated with [[masculinity]] while '[[beauty]]' has long been described as small, soft curvatures that "catch a man's eye" and thus, is defined as female.
Much of her work revolves around the parameters of feminist presence in art, music, and literature.{{cite book|last=Korsmeyer|first=Carolyn|title=Aesthetics in Feminist Perspective|url=https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=s6GSMUGGEmgC&oi=fnd&pg=PR7&dq=Carolyn+Korsmeyer&ots=PuYT_sCHvT&sig=MkrfyPnLMAJZFB6YSDop1CGKx00#v=onepage&q=Carolyn%20Korsmeyer&f=false|publisher=Hypatia, Inc|accessdate=2 August 2013}} In her book ''Aesthetics in Feminist Perspective'' Korsemeyer compares theories of art and the varying interpretations based on gender bias. Her publications on the subject include: *''Gender and Aesthetics: An Introduction'' (London: Routledge, 2004) *"Feminist Aesthetics", The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy (Winter 2012 Edition) *''Feminism and Tradition in Aesthetics'', edited with Peggy Zeglin Brand(Indiana University Press, 1993) == Honors and achievements == University at Buffalo Research Recognition Program awarded Korsmeyer their Sustained Achievement Exceptional Scholar Award to awknowledge her outstanding performance over a several year period in her body of work. In 2001, she won the Buffalo and Erie County Public Library's Mark Twain Creative Writing Competition by writing a chapter that concluded Twain's unpublished short story, ''A Murder, a Mystery and a Marriage.'' == External Links == * [https://library.brown.edu/collatoz/info.php?id=522/ Carolyn Korsmeyer Papers] -- Pembroke Center Archives, Brown University == References == {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Korsmeyer, Carolyn}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American women philosophers]] [[Category:American feminists]] [[Category:20th-century American philosophers]] [[Category:21st-century American philosophers]] [[Category:Feminist philosophers]] [[Category:Philosophers of art]] [[Category:1950 births]]

revision.text:
[[File:Elephant (Loxodonta africana) (6035902212).jpg|thumb|An elephant (''Loxodonta africana''), an example of a charismatic large animal species.]] '''Charismatic megafauna''' are [[megafauna|large animal species]] with [[symbol|symbolic value]], widespread popular appeal, and are often used by environmental activists to achieve [[environmentalist]] goals.<ref name="Charisma">{{cite journal |last=Ducarme |first=Frédéric |last2=Luque |first2=Gloria M. |last3=Courchamp |first3=Franck |year=2013 |title=What are "charismatic species" for conservation biologists ? |url=http://biologie.ens-lyon.fr/biologie/ressources/bibliographies/pdf/m1-11-12-biosci-reviews-ducarme-f-2c-m.pdf?lang=en |journal=BioSciences Master Reviews |volume=10 |pages=1–8 |doi= |accessdate=19 December 2013}}</ref> Examples include the [[humpback whale]], [[giant panda]], [[bald eagle]], [[California condor]], [[harp seal]], and [[penguin]].<ref>{{cite book |author1=Kaufman, Donald G. |author2=Franz, Cecilia M. |title=Biosphere 2000: Protecting Our Global Environment |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xBG99KR52mgC&pg=PA342 |date=2000 |publisher=Kendall Hunt Publishing Company |isbn=978-0-7872-5713-2 |page=342}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Penguins in peril |url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/1999/mar/27/naturaldisasters.world |website=The Guardian |publisher=The Guardian|date=1999}}</ref> Paradoxically, numerous charismatic species are [[Endangered species|endangered]] by [[hunting]] and [[black market]] commerce.<ref name="Courchamp2018">{{cite journal |last1=Courchamp |first1=F. |last2=Jaric |first2=I. |last3=Albert |first3=C. |last4=Meinard |first4=Y. |last5=Ripple |first5=W. J.|last6=Chapron |first6=G. |date=2018 |title=The paradoxical extinction of the most charismatic animals |url=http://journals.plos.org/plosbiology/article?id=10.1371/journal.pbio.2003997 |journal=[[PLOS Biology]] |volume=16 |issue=4 |page=e2003997 |doi=10.1371/journal.pbio.2003997 |access-date=}}</ref>
== Use in conservation == Charismatic species are often used as [[flagship species]] in conservation programs, as they are supposed to attract people's feelings more.<ref name="Charisma"/> However, being charismatic does not protect species against [[extinction]]: all of the 10 most charismatic species are currently [[endangered]], and only the giant panda shows a demographic growth from an extremely small population.<ref name=Courchamp2018/>
Beginning early in the 20th century, efforts to reintroduce extirpated charismatic megafauna to ecosystems have been an interest of a number of private and non-government conservation organizations.<ref>{{cite journal | last =Miller |first=C. R. |author2=Waits, L. P. |author3=Joyce, P. |title = Phylogeography and mitochondrial diversity of extirpated brown bear (''Ursus arctos'') populations in the contiguous United States and Mexico | journal = Molecular Ecology |volume =15 | issue=14 | pages =4477–4485 |date=2006 | doi =10.1111/j.1365-294X.2006.03097.x | pmid =17107477}}</ref> Species have been reintroduced from [[captive breeding]] programs in zoos, such as the European bison to Poland's [[Białowieża Forest]].<ref>{{cite journal | last = Mysterud | first =A. |author2=Bartoń, K. A. |author3=Jędrzejewska, B. |author4=Krasiński, Z. A. |author5=Niedziałkowska, M. |author6=Kamler, J. F. |author7=Yoccoz, N. G. |author8=Stenseth, N. C. | title=Population ecology and conservation of endangered megafauna: the case of European bison in Białowiez’a Primeval Forest, Poland |journal=Animal Conservation |volume=10 | issue=1| pages=77–87 |year =2007 |doi=10.1111/j.1469-1795.2006.00075.x}}</ref> These and other reintroductions of charismatic megafauna, such as [[Przewalski's horse]] to [[Mongolia]], have been to areas of limited, and often patchy range compared to the historic ranges of the respective species.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Rugenstein | first =Dustin R. |author2=Rubenstein, Daniel I. |author3=Sherman, Paul W. |author4=Gavin, Thomas A. |title=Pleistocene Park: Does re-wilding North America represent sound conservation for the 21st century? |journal=Biological Conservation |volume=132 |issue=2 |pages=232–238 |year=2006 |doi=10.1016/j.biocon.2006.04.003}}</ref>
Environmental activists and proponents of [[ecotourism]] seek to use the leverage provided by charismatic and well-known species to achieve more subtle and far-reaching goals in species and biodiversity conservation.{{Citation needed|date=June 2010}} By directing public attention to the diminishing numbers of giant panda due to [[habitat loss]], for example, conservation groups can raise support for the protection of the panda and for the entire [[ecosystem]] of which it is a part.{{Citation needed|date=May 2007}} (The giant panda is portrayed in the logo of the [[World Wide Fund for Nature]].)
== Taxonomic bias == Charismatic megafauna may be subject to [[taxonomic inflation]], in that taxonomists will declare a [[subspecies]] to be a [[species]] because of the advocacy benefits of a unique species, rather than because of new scientific evidence.<ref name="econ">[http://www.economist.com/opinion/displaystory.cfm?story_id=9191545 "Species inflation: Hail Linnaeus"], ''[[The Economist]]'', May 17, 2007</ref> The public's preference to identify with species sold through the [[ecotourism]] industry may be a factor for creating taxonomic inflation.<ref name=econ/> In the public perception, ecotourism may be about seeing species, and the number of unique species increases the perceived [[biodiversity]] and tourism [[Value (economics)|value]] of an area.<ref>{{cite book | last =Higham | first =James | title = Critical Issues in Ecotourism: understanding a complex tourism phenomenon | publisher=Butterworth-Heinemann |year =2007 |location = |pages =76–77 | isbn =0-7506-6878-4}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last =Weaver | first=D. | title=Ecotourism | publisher = John Wiley & Sons Australia Ltd |year=2002 |isbn =0-471-42230-4 |page=113}}</ref> A correlation may exist between the taxonomic bias in biodiversity datasets and the charisma of terrestrial megafauna, with the more charismatic species being largely over-reported.<ref>{{cite journal|last1 =Monsarrat |last2 =Kerley| first1=S. | first2=G.I.H | title=Charismatic species of the past: Biases in reporting of large mammals in historical written sources| journal= Biological Conservation |year=2018| volume=223 | DOI= 10.1016/j.biocon.2018.04.036 | page=68-75}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Bambi effect]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==Further reading== * {{cite journal | author1 = Petersen, Shannon | year = 1999 | title = Congress and charismatic megafauna: a legislative history of the Endangered Species Act | journal = Environmental Law | volume = 29}} * {{cite book | year = 2000 |author1=Leader-Williams, N. |author2=H. T. Dublin | chapter = Charismatic megafauna as 'flagship species' | title = Priorities for the Conservation of Mammalian Diversity: Has the Panda had its Day? | editor = Entwistle, A. and N. Dunstone | pages = 53–81 | location = Cambridge | publisher = Cambridge University Press | isbn = 0-521-77279-6}} * {{cite book | year = 2000 |author1=Goodwin, H. |author2=N. Leader-Williams | chapter = Tourism and protected areas – distorting conservation priorities towards charismatic megafauna? | editor = Entwistle, A. and N. Dunstone | title = Priorities for the Conservation of Mammalian Biodiversity: Has the Panda had its Day? | location = Cambridge | publisher = Cambridge University Press | pages = 257–275 | isbn = 0-521-77279-6}} * {{cite journal|last1=Barney|first1=Erin C.|last2=Mintzes|first2=Joel J.|last3=Yen|first3=Chiung-Fen|title=Assessing knowledge, attitudes, and behavior toward charismatic megafauna: The case of dolphins|journal=The Journal of Environmental Education|date=January 2005|volume=36|issue=2|pages=41–55|doi=10.3200/JOEE.36.2.41-55}}
[[Category:Conservation biology]]
